head.title: An Urban Headache: Not Enough Housing

hedline.hl1: An Urban Headache: Not Enough Housing

abstract.p: Jamie Smarr letter says New York City's housing crisis stems in part from continuing occupancy of middle-income housing by people whose incomes have risen (S)

Re ''Housing Crisis Confounds a Prosperous City'' (news article, July 9):

While it is true that New York's housing shortage could be ameliorated with increased public financing and a renewed political commitment, the present crisis is also partly a result of middle- and upper-middle-class New Yorkers who deprive needy families of housing opportunities. One example is the Mitchell-Lama Housing Program.

Since 1955, the program has constructed approximately 110,000 units of moderate- and middle-income housing for New Yorkers. Originally, strict income guidelines were observed. Today, single elderly tenants occupy three- and four-bedroom apartments. Rich families use the apartments as weekend pieds-a-terre and city vacation homes, refusing to move even when their income dictates it.
And state and city housing officials and politicians ignore this problem, no doubt because many of them occupy such housing.
